Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: The meeting is a routine catch-up that will be recorded for anyone who cannot make it.
Story: It’s Saturday afternoon, and my phone buzzes with a message from my stepmom: “Haven’t heard from you in a while. Hope you’re okay!” I know she worries if I don’t check in, and my dad always says it means a lot to her when I reach out. I start typing a reply, but just then, my work calendar pings—a reminder for the weekly team catch-up. It’s not urgent, and the meeting will be recorded, but my manager always expects everyone to show up and contribute, even on weekends. I can already picture the awkward silence if I’m not there to give my project update. My thumb hovers over the “Join Meeting” button, but I can’t shake the guilt of leaving my stepmom’s message unanswered. I feel torn, the weight of both expectations pressing down on me. I want to be a good stepchild, to show I care, but I also don’t want to let my team down or seem disengaged. My heart races as I stare at my phone, caught between two worlds, unsure which one to choose.
